contentHtml: #111. What's the output? let name = 'Lydia'; function getName() { console.log(name); let name = 'Sarah'; } getName(); javascript A: Lydia B: Sarah C: undefined D: ReferenceError Answer Answer: D Each function has its own execution context (or scope). The getName function first looks within its own context (scope) to see if it contains the variable name we're trying to access. In this case, the getName function contains its own name variable: we d
